thread.title: Brexit & Beyond: Zuckerberg Enters the Lion’s Den

author: WSJ Staff
title: Brexit & Beyond: Zuckerberg Enters the Lion’s Den
text:
0 COMMENTS To subscribe to the newsletter, please sign up here
MUST READS
Zuckerberg Enters the Lion’s Den: Privacy-Focused Europe : Top European lawmakers are set to interrogate Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg on Tuesday over the company’s handling of alleged data misuse and election interference on the platform, as the tech giant seeks to appease officials in a region where it is regulated strictly.
What Could Facebook’s Zuckerberg Be Quizzed on at European Hearing? : If you thought Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg got off too easy in his recent testimony before Congress, you may want to tune in when he speaks to European lawmakers.
Italy’s Coalition Parties Pick Political Novice to Lead : Italy’s two anti-establishment parties chose a political novice to become the country’s next prime minister, allowing party leaders to potentially act as the powers behind the throne.
Spain Maintains Direct Rule Over Catalonia Due to ‘Provocative’ Regional Government : The restive Catalonia region has a new leader but Spain’s prime minister has maintained direct rule, prolonging the tense relationship between Catalan separatists and the central government.
Why Are Two of Europe’s Star Currencies Selling Off? : Dollar bulls are rarely good news for emerging markets. Among those feeling the pinch are two of Europe’s star currencies from 2017: Poland’s zloty has dropped 7.7% against a resurgent dollar over the past month, one of the steepest declines within emerging markets; Hungary’s forint has not been far behind, shedding 7.2%.
Bank of England Could Raise Rates in Coming Months, Carney Says : The Bank of England is likely to raise its key interest rate in “a few months” if the U.K. economy’s first-quarter slowdown proves to be short-lived, a member of its Monetary Policy Committee said Tuesday.
Cambridge Analytica Staff Told Firm Is Liquidating : Cambridge Analytica, the firm at the heart of Facebook’s data scandal, is liquidating assets and has asked workers to vacate its London office, according to employees.
U.K. Lawmakers Call for Tougher Crackdown on Illicit Russian Funds : An influential group of British lawmakers criticized the U.K. government for not doing enough to clamp down on illicit Russian money, as it emerged that a prominent oligarch hadn’t been able to enter Britain in recent weeks because of a delay in his visa renewal.
Emotional Tributes Open First Phase of Inquiry Into London’s Grenfell Fire : Britain began the first phase of its public inquiry into the Grenfell Tower blaze with emotional memorials to some of the 72 people killed nearly a year ago.
Britain Unlikely to Review Comcast’s $30 Billion Sky Deal : Britain is unlikely to open an antitrust review into Comcast’s $30 billion bid for U.K. pay-television company Sky, a senior government official said Monday, removing a hurdle for the cable firm in a takeover battle that also includes 21st Century Fox and Walt Disney.

Iran Tells Europe to Step Up and Save Nuclear Deal – Reuters
Manchester, ‘City in Recovery,’ to Mark Anniversary of Attack – New York Times
